body.raw:
# John Doe

John Doe is a software engineer at TechCorp with over 10 years of experience in the tech industry. He specializes in AI and machine learning.

## Background

John holds a Ph.D. in Computer Science from MIT and has worked on various AI projects.

## Contact

- Email: [john.doe@example.com](mailto:john.doe@example.com)
- Twitter: [@johndoe](https://twitter.com/johndoe)
- LinkedIn: [John Doe](https://linkedin.com/in/john-doe)
- GitHub: [johndoe](https://github.com/johndoe)

document.title: An Army of Agents
document.summary: An approachable introduction to AI agents and why they're likely to be the most impactful technology of our generation.

body.raw:
# An Introduction to MDX

MDX is a format that lets you seamlessly use JSX in your Markdown documents. This makes it possible to use React components within Markdown content, allowing for a powerful combination of documentation and interactive examples.

## Why Use MDX?

Using MDX provides several benefits:
- **Interactive Content**: Embed interactive components and visualizations directly within your Markdown.
- **Component Reusability**: Reuse React components across multiple Markdown files.
- **Dynamic Content**: Generate dynamic content using JavaScript and React within Markdown.

## Getting Started

To start using MDX in your project, you can follow these steps:

1. **Install MDX Dependencies**:
   ```bash
   npm install @mdx-js/react

structuredData.headline: An Army of Agents
structuredData.description: An approachable introduction to AI agents and why they're likely to be the most impactful technology of our generation.

document.title: ChatGPT Twitter Bot: Lessons from over 100k Conversations
document.summary: A breakdown of everything I've learned running the ChatGPT twitter bot over the past two months.
